div.p: The Shadow Hills development began in 1907 and was marketed as “Little Farms Near the City”(Barraclough, 176). As Barraclough writes, “Non whites were deliberately excluded from the ideals of suburban farming through the Alien Land Laws, which forbade land ownership of by ‘aliens ineligible for citizenship’”(175). Non whites could not acquire property and were relegated to other suburban spaces such as colonias of San Fernando and Sun Valley. Throughout the 1960s San Fernando Valley rural areas began to subdivide for new commercial development. However, Shadow Hills “activists” would zone the subdivision as a “horse raising zone” to protect the community from future zoning laws. As Barraclough explains, “Shadow Hills and adjacent white communities could preserve their single-family, low-density landscape and rural lifestyle”(176). This community highlights the continuation of racial segregation and protection of rural aesthetic that is inaccessible to non whites.

note.p: Shadow Hills suburban development demonstrates the historical continuity of racial covenants and homogenous social and economic enslaves.
